image.altText: Toya Raj Bhattarai looks at the camera.

props.synopsis: Business owner Toya says he has faced repeated racial abuse, and he says it's no longer safe for his wife and children to go to the park. There are calls for stronger laws and better data collection to help address the problem.

title.children: 'Everyone is scared': Migrants in Tasmania say they're facing increased incidents of racism

image.altText: A woman in her twenties with long dark brown hair smiling

props.synopsis: Burnie woman Jordi Apted lived with the "crippling pain" of endometriosis for years before getting surgery through the private health system. She hopes other women don't have to share that experience.

title.children: Surgical robot, outpatient endometriosis services pledged by Tasmanian Liberals ahead of election

image.altText: A red sign with white writing that says 'rent' in capital letters that obscures a weatherboard house in the background.

props.synopsis: New data confirms what most renters already know — there has not been a worse time to be a tenant in at least the past 17 years.

title.children: Rental affordability has gone from record highs to record lows in the space of three years. What went wrong?

image.altText: Jumana

props.synopsis: Jumana is just one of many young people trapped inside Gaza. For months she has documented her family's attempt to escape to safety. This is her story.

title.children: Sheltering in a room with her family in Gaza, Jumana is desperate to make it to Australia before the invasion

image.altText: A close up of Kate Middleton smiling while wearing dangly earings.

props.synopsis: For centuries, the British monarchy has shrouded itself in mystery while allowing the occasional glimpse over palace walls. But when the star royal wanted to convalesce in private, some of her future subjects revolted.

title.children: The House of Windsor has long contended with wild conspiracy theories, but the frenzy around Kate's health is beyond public interest

image.altText: A smiling woman with two children, their faces pixelated

props.synopsis: Ballarat locals are being encouraged to reach out for help as they struggle to process the disappearance of Samantha Murphy and arrest of a local man.

title.children: Grief over Samantha Murphy is complicated by arrest of local man, Ballarat mayor says

image.altText: A cupcake with green icing, upside down and a bit smashed, on the floor

props.synopsis: "Count Her In!" was the theme for yesterday's International Women's Day, and this year Australian womanhood had the chance to leaf through the newly released pay gap data over their celebratory cupcakes, writes Annabel Crabb.

title.children: A spicy new ingredient gave rise to some awkward morning teas in corporate Australia

image.altText: Aavaisha is wearing a white dress and getting her makeup done with bright pink eyeshadow

props.synopsis: Nine First Nations designers and artists with wearable garments are showing their new collections at the Melbourne Fashion Festival this weekend.

title.children: Can anyone wear First Nations fashion? Designers have their say

image.altText: A Fiji minister stands next to a flag.

props.synopsis: In the same week a prominent female Fiji MP was demoted after an alleged affair, two Solomon Islands female MPs announced they would not be contesting next month's election. The kicker? They'd be replaced by their husbands.

title.children: Two female MPs in the Pacific have been replaced by their husbands, another demoted after alleged 'sex scandal'

image.altText: A neon outline of the Asia Pacific region.

props.synopsis: 'Happiness' brain chips, a missing jumbo jet and genuine fears of a conflict with North Korea — here's what happened in the Asia Pacific this week.

title.children: North Korea threatens war as brain technology promises happiness — this week in the Asia Pacific

image.altText: Marnus Labuschagne puts his hand to his head while carrying his batting gear

props.synopsis: Australia will be hoping to seize the advantage on day two of the second Test against New Zealand at Christchurch's Hagley Oval. Follow the action in our live blog.

title.children: Australia bowled out with a lead of 94 runs on day two of Christchurch Test

liveBlogKeyEvents.title: OUT! Cummins is out LBW and Australia is all out for 257
WHAT A CATCH! WHAT A CATCH!

image.altText: Anwar Ibrahim and Anthony Albanese stand next to each other, solemnly looking out into the distance

props.synopsis: Malaysia's Prime Minister Anwar Ibrahim shared his thoughts on topics from China to Shakespeare while in Australia.

title.children: 'The world does not need that': Malaysian PM questions Australia's relationship with China

image.altText: Four police officers with fluro vests examine a scene in the dark near police vehicles.

props.synopsis: A woman aged in her 20s, who was armed with a knife, has been shot dead by police after officers responded to reports of a woman assaulting another woman in the north-east suburb of Lower Plenty.

title.children: Police shoot woman dead while responding to fatal assault in Melbourne

image.altText: A koala nestles into the fork of a gum tree.

props.synopsis: The footage emerged this week of logging operations on Kangaroo Island where tree plantations and the koala population have had a complex relationship since devastating bushfires in 2019-20.

title.children: 'Horrific' vision of koalas scrambling, falling as trees cut down spurs government action

image.altText: A 15 year old girl and red cattle

props.synopsis: While other teens saved up for a car or a new phone, 15-year-old Matilda Herron was saving up for her first bull. But when that chance came, it was through an unexpected tragedy.

title.children: Teen spends life savings to preserve neighbour's cattle-breeding legacy after sudden death

image.altText: Composite of Oppenheimer, Barbie, and Poor Things.

props.synopsis: From Oppenheimer to Poor Things, which films will win the big awards at Hollywood's night of nights? Our experts cast their votes.

title.children: Who can pick the 2024 Oscar winners more accurately — a film critic or a mathematician?

image.altText: A brown spider with long, hairy legs balances on a man's hands

props.synopsis: Animal behaviouralist James O'Hanlon is debunking five long-held myths about spiders and is sharing his own skin-crawling encounter in the process.

title.children: Do we really eat spiders in our sleep? This scientist busts five common arachnid myths

image.altText: Bluey and Bingo characters promoting greyhound race event.

props.synopsis: The Tasmanian Trotting Club defends the use of cartoon dog duo Bluey and Bingo to promote a Good Friday family racing event — and denies it's in breach of any copyright law.

title.children: Sports club defends use of Bluey characters to promote greyhound racing event

image.altText: the sun behind clouds creates orange and yellow glow during sunrise at Storm Bay in Tasmania

props.synopsis: The calendar rolls into autumn but Australia's weather still firmly resembles mid-summer, including the most intense autumn heatwave in decades across South Australia and Victoria.

title.children: Near-record autumn heat bakes south-east while cyclone threat returns to Australia's north

image.altText: A man bites into a sandwich on white bread containing a steak and salad.

props.synopsis: Consisting of steak wrapped around ham and cheese and covered with breadcrumbs, the dish has become part of the Victorian city's identity.

title.children: It was voted Australia's worst regional food, but the steak 'florrie' has put Horsham on the map

image.altText: A man stands on a wharf with his crossed arms.

props.synopsis: People with disabilities need visibility and role models, something this fishing program helps create — along with fun and friendships.

title.children: After growing up with a disability, Timothy knew he had to help others, so he cast his net wide

image.altText: A greeny blue channel between white capped waves breaking into the shore.

props.synopsis: Rips are the number one coastal hazard contributing to a number of deaths each year so how do you spot one and what should you do if you're caught in one?

title.children: What is a rip at the beach and how do you safely swim out of one?

image.altText: A person in a spacesuit kneels on the surface of the moon.

props.synopsis: Leaving Earth for long periods requires highly specialised technical skills, but you also need to handle isolation, confined quarters and team conflict.

title.children: Mars travel will resemble being stuck in an elevator with the same people for years. Would you do it?

image.altText: Raye sitting down wearing long maroon high heeled boots, a grey guitar, drum kit and speakers behind her

props.synopsis: British singer-songwriter Raye made history when she won six Brit Awards this week. It's been a long road to the top for the pop star, who was on the verge of giving up her dream before her breakthrough and awards dominance.

title.children: Raye's recognition at the Brit Awards was borne out of blood, sweat and years

image.altText: a table of photos of Samantha and flowers.

props.synopsis: The Ballarat community has gathered for a vigil to honour Samantha Murphy after a 22-year-old man was charged with her alleged murder.

title.children: Ballarat community gather to support the family of missing mother Samantha Murphy

image.altText: Middle-aged woman wearing blue floral top stands smiling in a rose garden.

props.synopsis: After hearing stories of people sleeping in their cars to access VAD medication discreetly, or spending their last nights in hospital, regional Victorian hospice Rosehaven designed a support program for patients and families.

title.children: 'Groundbreaking' hospice program helps patients avoid loneliness in voluntary assisted dying process

image.altText: A man sits in front of a screen with lots of numbers

props.synopsis: Pepe King already holds several Australian maths records. Now he will be attempting to break a world record by multiplying two 40-digit numbers in under 40 minutes.

title.children: Man who failed maths at school prepares to tackle multiplication world record

image.altText: ECQ logo on an envelope for a postal vote.

props.synopsis: With so many councillor and mayor positions uncontested, is it a sign of voter disengagement or are people happy with how things are?

title.children: It's a well-paid job so why are fewer people nominating for local councils?

image.altText: A person in a spacesuit kneels on the surface of the moon.

props.synopsis: Leaving Earth for long periods requires highly specialised technical skills, but you also need to handle isolation, confined quarters and team conflict.

title.children: Mars travel will resemble being stuck in an elevator with the same people for years. Would you do it?

image.altText: Middle-aged woman wearing blue floral top stands smiling in a rose garden.

props.synopsis: After hearing stories of people sleeping in their cars to access VAD medication discreetly, or spending their last nights in hospital, regional Victorian hospice Rosehaven designed a support program for patients and families.

title.children: 'Groundbreaking' hospice program helps patients avoid loneliness in voluntary assisted dying process

image.altText: A teenage boy with long brown hair, a black shirt and brown cap and glasses sitting at a desk drawing a picture.

props.synopsis: Macklyn Woollard is one of more than 200,000 people living with autism in Australia. Despite the size of the neurodiverse community, the WA teenager says he struggles to find like-minded people being celebrated in the media.

title.children: How more neurodiversity in the media would help teenagers like Macklyn achieve their dreams

image.altText: Tennis player Alex de Minaur hits a forehand during a Mexican Open match against Stefanos Tsitsipas.

props.synopsis: Australia's top ranked male tennis player smashes his way to the round of 32 at Indian Wells as other Aussies fall.

title.children: Dominant de Minaur continues his roll at Indian Wells as Kokkinakis falls to Sinner

image.altText: Justis Huni

props.synopsis: Australia's Justis Huni survives a final round scare against his South African opponent in Saudi Arabia to keep his unbeaten record intact.

title.children: 'He stayed up like a tough lion': Queenslander Huni weathers a vicious barrage in Saudi Arabia to remain undefeated

image.altText: Jakara Anthony

props.synopsis: Australia's Jakara Anthony claims her 12th win of the moguls season and breaks American Hannah Kearney's record in doing so.

title.children: Aussie moguls star Jakara Anthony wins again to break the record of her American idol
